How does maze.py use search

Basic search usage in maze.py script

The maze.py script follows the basic usage pattern of the search module described in User Guide:

  1. Import interface classes Node and SearchProblem

  2. Create its own maze problem specific derived classes: Maze and MazeNode

  3. Write/override methods that implement maze specific problem environment

  4. Call search module interface methods

Lest see each step:

1. Import interface classes Node and SearchProblem

from search import Node, SearchProblem

2. Create its own maze problem specific derived classes: Maze and MazeNode

class Maze(SearchProblem):
   ...

class MazeNode(Node):
   ...

Those classes details, as follows:

Maze class

class maze.Maze(filename, start_char='A', goal_char='B', path_char=' ')[source]

Bases: SearchProblem

Defines a maze object to be solved with ‘search’ module.

Subclasses SearchProblem class, to:

Implement __init__() with attributes that define maze layout

Override show_solution() to print static maze layout with solution and dynamic maze path forming

Override save_algorithm_steps_to_file() to add static maze print to file.

Parameters:

  • filename (str)

  • start_char (str)

  • goal_char (str)

  • path_char (str)

filename

Name of the UTF-8 text file defining the maze.

Type:

str

start_char

Character representing the start point in maze file.

Type:

str

goal_char

Character representing the goal point in maze file.

Type:

str

path_char

Character representing the open path in maze file.

Type:

str

walls

Boolean grid representing walls (True) and open paths (False) in maze.

Type:

list of list of bool

height

Number of rows in the maze.

Type:

int

width

Number of columns in the maze.

Type:

int

offset

Directional offsets (horizontal, vertical) for movement.

Type:

dict

first_dynamic_solution_shown

Tracks if a dynamic solution was displayed.

Type:

bool

layout_elements

Styling for maze components during visualization.

Type:

dict

maze_solution_layout

Stores elements for dynamic maze display.

Type:

dict

start_node

Node object for the maze start position.

Type:

MazeNode

goal_node

Node object for the maze goal position.

Type:

MazeNode

Notes on maze layout definition file:

Maze layout is defined in an utf-8 encoded text file. Each character in file represents a cell in maze grid. Cells can be:

  • starting cell (default character is ‘A’)

  • goal cell (default character is ‘B’)

  • path (default character is ‘ ‘)

  • wall (any other character)

Maze layout file content example:

‘###########’ ‘# #’ ‘#### #### #’ ‘#B # #’ ‘# #### ####’ ‘# #’ ‘#A#########’

MazeNode class

class maze.MazeNode(state=None, parent=None, action=None)[source]

Bases: Node

Represents a node in the maze.

A MazeNode is mainly the position in the maze. It also includes the previous position and the direction taken to get there, although these are used sparsely.

Subclasses Node class, to implement actions() and result() methods according to a maze layout. It also overrides __repr__ to be used in Maze methods printing nodes.

Parameters:

  • state (object | None)

  • parent (Node | None)

  • action (object | None)

state

The current position in the maze as a tuple (row, column).

Type:

tuple

parent

The parent node from which this node was reached.

Type:

MazeNode

action

The action taken to reach this node from the parent node.

Type:

str

3. Write/override methods that implement maze specific problem environment

The following methods are created or overridden to define the maze-specific environment:

class Maze(SearchProblem):
   def __init__():
      ...

   def show_solution():
      ...

   def save_algorithm_steps_to_file()
      ...


class MazeNode(Node):
   def actions():
      ...

   def result():
      ...

   def __repr__():
      ...

Lets see each method detail:

maze.Maze.__init__()

Maze.__init__(filename, start_char='A', goal_char='B', path_char=' ')[source]

Reads maze layout from ‘filename’ to initialize a maze object.

Parameters:

  • filename (str) – name of utf-8 text file .txt defining maze layout.

  • start_char (str, optional) – The character representing the start position in the maze. Defaults to ‘A’.

  • goal_char (str, optional) – The character representing the goal position in the maze. Defaults to ‘B’.

  • path_char (str, optional) – The character representing the path in the maze. Defaults to ‘ ‘.

Return type:

None

maze.Maze.show_solution()

Maze.show_solution(dynamic=False)[source]

Prints the maze and its solution.

Parameters:

dynamic (bool) – If True, shows the solution step by step dynamically.

Returns:

True if the solution was shown successfully, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

Raises:

curses.error – If there is an error showing the dynamic solution.

maze.Maze.save_algorithm_steps_to_file()

Maze.save_algorithm_steps_to_file()[source]

Saves algorithm steps to a file.

Overrides base method to save maze graphic solution. The file name saved is the same as the layout filename read, ending in _<algorithm name>_steps.txt.

The file contains a summary of the solution and the maze layout with the solution path.

Return type:

None

maze.MazeNode.actions()

MazeNode.actions(search_problem)[source]

List of valid movements (actions) to occupy contiguous cells.

This method determines the valid actions that can be performed from the current position in the maze, considering the maze boundaries and walls.

Parameters:

search_problem (SearchProblem) – The search problem instance containing the maze layout, including the offset information, dimensions, and wall positions.

Returns:

A list of valid actions (str) that can be performed from the current position.

Return type:

list

maze.MazeNode.result()

MazeNode.result(action, search_problem)[source]

Returns the node that results from performing ‘action’ on self.

Calculates the new position in the maze based on the given action and the search problem’s offset.

Parameters:

  • action (str) – The action to be performed.

  • search_problem (SearchProblem) – The search problem instance containing the offset information.

Returns:

A new MazeNode instance representing the new position in the maze.

Return type:

MazeNode

Raises:

ValueError – If the action is not valid.

maze.MazeNode.__repr__()

MazeNode.__repr__()[source]

Returns a string representation of the object.

This method provides a simple view of the object, omitting details.

Returns:

A string representation of the object, including its state and action.

Return type:

str

4. Call search module interface methods

As we saw in User Guide, the script calls search module interface methods:

  • maze.Maze.solve()

  • maze.Maze.show_solution()

  • maze.Maze.save_algorithm_steps_to_file()

These method calls are made within the main() function of the script. Two example functions illustrate their usage:

  • maze.search_module_simple_usage_example()

  • maze.dynamic_solution_display_search_usage_example()
